What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(4) APIs: The Lubricant for Fast Flow

  • Digital Transformation focuses on digital processes and opportunities
  • APIs are the connective tissue of everything digital
  • Having APIs as Team Interfaces improves collaboration and coordination
  • Documentation-First APIs [documentation] improve human collaboration (good)
  • Specification-First APIs [client-tooling] also improve tooling support (better)


What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(5) APIs are Languages [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDYeU2T4v2o]



What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(6) API Styles

  1. Tunnel Style: XML-RPC, SOAP, gRPC, Avro
  2. Resource Style: OpenAPI, RAML, API Blueprint
  3. Hypermedia Style: HAL, Siren, Atom, JSON:API
  4. Query Style: GraphQL, OData, SPARQL
  5. Event-Oriented Style: MQ, WebSub, MQTT, XMPP, AMQP, Kafka, AsyncAPI


What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

OpenAPI Anatomy Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(16) A Brief History of OpenAPI

  • Started out in 2011 and was called Swagger [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swagger_(software)] for quite a while
    • Competing approaches like RAML [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RAML_(software)] and API Blueprint [https://github.com/apiaryio/api-blueprint] exist
  • Swagger was renamed to OpenAPI at the beginning of 2016
    • Donated to the OpenAPI Initiative (OAI) [https://www.openapis.org/] (part of the Linux Foundation [https://www.linuxfoundation.org/])
    • Swagger [https://swagger.io/tools/open-source/] now refers to a specific tool offered by SmartBear [https://smartbear.com/]
  • OpenAPI has been the official name since 2016 with three main versions
    • OpenAPI 2.0 was the name after the rename (it's the same as Swagger 2.0)
    • OpenAPI 3.0 was released in July 2017
    • OpenAPI 3.1 was released in February 2021


OpenAPI Anatomy Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(17) Discovery and Getting Started 

openapi: 3.0.2
info:
  title: Swagger Petstore - OpenAPI 3.0
  description: "This is a sample Pet Store Server based on the OpenAPI 3.0 specification.\
    \  You can find out more about\nSwagger at [http://swagger.io](http://swagger.io).\
    \ In the third iteration of the pet store, we've switched to the design first\
    \ approach!\nYou can now help us improve the API whether it's by making changes\
    \ to the definition itself or to the code.\nThat way, with time, we can improve\
    \ the API in general, and expose some of the new features in OAS3.\n\nSome useful\
    \ links:\n- [The Pet Store repository](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-petstore)\n\
    - [The source API definition for the Pet Store](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-petstore/blob/master/src/main/resources/openapi.yaml)"
  termsOfService: http://swagger.io/terms/
  contact:
    email: apiteam@swagger.io
  license:
    name: Apache 2.0
    url: http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html
  version: 1.0.17
externalDocs:
  description: Find out more about Swagger
  url: http://swagger.io
servers:
- url: /api/v3
  • petstore-openapi.yaml (line 1-23)


OpenAPI Anatomy Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(18) Paths: The Resources of an API 

  /pet/{petId}:
    get:
      tags:
      - pet
      summary: Find pet by ID
      description: Returns a single pet
      operationId: getPetById
      parameters:
      - name: petId
        in: path
        description: ID of pet to return
        required: true
        schema:
          type: integer
          format: int64
      responses:
        "200":
          description: successful operation
          content:
            application/xml:
              schema:
                $ref: '#/components/schemas/Pet'
            application/json:
              schema:
                $ref: '#/components/schemas/Pet'
        "400":
          description: Invalid ID supplied
        "404":
          description: Pet not found
      security:
      - api_key: []
      - petstore_auth:
        - write:pets
        - read:pets
  • petstore-openapi.yaml (line 191-224)


OpenAPI Anatomy Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(19) Interactions with Resources 

  /pet/findByStatus:
    get:
      tags:
      - pet
      summary: Finds Pets by status
      description: Multiple status values can be provided with comma separated strings
      operationId: findPetsByStatus
      parameters:
      - name: status
        in: query
        description: Status values that need to be considered for filter
        required: false
        explode: true
        schema:
          type: string
          default: available
          enum:
          - available
          - pending
          - sold
      responses:
        "200":
          description: successful operation
          content:
            application/xml:
              schema:
                type: array
                items:
                  $ref: '#/components/schemas/Pet'
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: array
                items:
                  $ref: '#/components/schemas/Pet'
        "400":
          description: Invalid status value
      security:
      - petstore_auth:
        - write:pets
        - read:pets
  • petstore-openapi.yaml (line 113-152)


OpenAPI Anatomy Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(20) OpenAPI 3.1: Of Callbacks and Webhooks

  • OpenAPI keeps evolving (3.1 released in February 2021)
  • OpenAPI 4.0 is being discussed under codename Moonwalk [https://github.com/OAI/moonwalk/discussions]
  • OpenAPI Special Interest Groups (SIG) [https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/discussions/2695] discuss topics related to OpenAPI
  • Callbacks allow specific resources to callback to a supplied URI
  • Webhooks are callbacks but unrelated to specific events


OpenAPI Anatomy Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(21) Webhooks in OpenAPI 3.1 

openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Webhook Example
  version: 1.0.0
# Since OAS 3.1.0 the paths element isn't necessary. Now a valid OpenAPI Document can describe only paths, webhooks, or even only reusable components
webhooks:
  # Each webhook needs a name
  newPet:
    # This is a Path Item Object, the only difference is that the request is initiated by the API provider
    post:
      requestBody:
        description: Information about a new pet in the system
        content:
          application/json:
            schema:
              $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"
      responses:
        "200":
          description: Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

components:
  schemas:
    Pet:
      required:
        - id
        - name
      properties:
        id:
          type: integer
          format: int64
        name:
          type: string
        tag:
          type: string
  • webhook-example-openapi.yaml

(25) Supporting Client-Side Tooling

  • OpenAPI is useful for producers and consumers
  • Make OpenAPI descriptions available to consumers


Better API Products with OpenAPI Erik Wilde (@dret): A Gentle Introduction to OpenAPI

(26) Mocking

  • When the real API doesn't yet exist
  • When the real API doesn't have a proper sandbox
  • When integration testing needs external components
